page.title: Final Check
page.introduction:
You have arrived at the end of the PAWS Starter Kit. As a final check of your work before you exit PAWS for the last time and begin working with the PC-Patr grammar file and the grammar writer files, any WARNING messages shown here need to be dealt with. These messages either tell you that you did not answer a question that has check boxes or that the answers you gave to two different questions are incompatible. Remember that if your language does not seem to have a particular construction, you should check the ‘Other’ option so you can say what your language does instead.
For each message shown, go to the page listed and make the appropriate corrections and then return here. That message should no longer show up.
If you do not correct these issues, the PC-Patr grammar rules and the grammar writeup will not be correct for your language. It will be much easier to correct these issues within PAWS, so please do not proceed until there are no WARNING messages showing below this box.
Note that if you dealt with the WARNING messages on each page earlier, you should not see any here now. Only those you missed or skipped will show up

form.prompt:
From
Quantifiers and QP, on the first page, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe how these degree elements or quantifiers attach in your language, or change the answer above to ‘Yes, they are all independent words’.

From
Quantifiers and QP, on the first page, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these degree words or quantifiers occur with respect to the rest of the nominal phrase in your language, or change the answer above to ‘No, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase’.

From
Quantifiers and QP - No other determiners, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these quantifiers occur with respect to the rest of the nominal phrase in your language, or change the answer above to "No, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase".

From
Quantifiers and QP - No other determiners, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe how these quantifiers attach in your language, or change the answer above to "Yes, they are all independent words".

From
Quantifiers and QP - Other Quantifiers and Degree Words, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these degree words occur with respect to the quantifier in your language or change your answer above to say that the degree elements are not expressed as independent words.

From
Quantifiers and QP - Other Quantifiers and Degree Words, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these degree affixes occur with respect to the quantifier in your language or change your answer above to say that the degree elements are all written as independent words.

From
Quantifiers and QP - Numbers, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe how the ordinal numbers are formed in your language.

From
Quantifiers and QP - Numbers, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where the ordinal word occurs with respect to the cardinal nunber to form the ordinal number in your language, or change your answer above to say that the the ordinal numbers are formed in another way.

From
Quantifiers and QP - Numbers, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where the ordinal numbers and the words for ‘last’ and ‘next’ occur with respect to the cardinal number.

From
Adverbs and AdvP, on the first page, WARNING: You said above that temporal adverbs may be modified or intensified, but you did not check any of the options. Please either check one or more options as appropriate, or change the answer above to "No, temporal adverbs are not modified or intensified".

Nominal Phrases - Agreement, WARNING: You said above that nouns and their modifiers may/must agree in other features besides number, but you did not check any of the options. Please either check one or more options as appropriate, or change the answer above to ‘No’.

From
Nominal Phrases - Agreement, WARNING: You said in
Overall Typology Questions - Classifiers your language has a classifier system with concord agreement, so you should check that they agree in class number or type here.

From
Nominal Phrases - Agreement, WARNING: You said in
Overall Typology Questions - Classifiers your language has a classifier system with concord agreement, so you should change your answer here to "Yes" and then check that they agree in class number or type.

From
Nominal Phrases - Agreement, WARNING: You said in
Overall Typology Questions - Classifiers that your language does not have a classifier system, so you should not check that they agree in class number or type here. If your language does have a classifier agreement system, please return to
Overall Typology Questions - Classifiers and change your answer there before continuing here.

From
Nominal Phrases - Agreement, WARNING: You said in
Overall Typology Questions - Classifiers your language has a simpler type of classifier system that does not include concord agreement within the nominal phrase, so you should not check that they agree in class number or type here. If your language does have a classifier agreement system and agreement is required, please return to
Overall Typology Questions - Classifiers and change your answer there before continuing here.

From

Please either check one or more options as appropriate, unless you do not have any reflexives, in which case you should not have added any forms to the text boxes and should change the answer above to either ‘No’ or ‘Yes, a verbal affix indicates reflexive action’.

From
Pronouns - Reciprocals, WARNING: You said above that your language has reciprocals, but you did not check any of the options to say how they are formed. From
Adpositional Phrases - Other Complements, WARNING: Since your language has only clitic prepositions, postpositions, prepositions and postpositions, it should not be possible for them to stand alone. If you do have forms which can stand alone, go back to the first page of this section and change the answer to ‘Some are written as independent words, but some are clitics written attached to another word’.

From
Basic Sentences - Agreement Features, WARNING: In
Pronouns you said that your language does not distinguish between exclusive and inclusive forms of the pronouns, yet you have checked some exclusive and inclusive features here. If your language does have exclusive and inclusive forms for any of the pronouns, including the dependent forms that can show up on verbs, please return to
Pronouns (first page) and change your answer to ‘Yes’. That will add additional textboxes for you to fill in for those forms for each appropriate case. If instead your language really does not distinguish between exclusive and inclusive features, please uncheck those features above.

From
Basic Sentences - Agreement Features, WARNING: In
Pronouns you said that your language has dependent pronouns and makes a distinction between exclusive and inclusive forms of the pronouns, yet you have not checked any exclusive or inclusive features here. It is therefore most likely that you need to check some or all of the exclusive and inclusive features above. Otherwise, please return to
Pronouns (first page) and change your answer to ‘No’, but that will mean that any forms you keyed in those textboxes will not be included in any output.

From
Basic Sentences - Agreement Features, WARNING: In
Pronouns you said that your language does not have different forms for singular and plural pronouns, yet you have checked some number features here. If your language does have singular and plural forms for any of the pronouns, including the dependent forms that can show up on verbs, please return to
Pronouns (first page) and change your answer to ‘Yes’. That will add additional textboxes for you to fill in for those forms for each appropriate case. If instead your language really does not distinguish between number features, please uncheck those features above.

From
Basic Sentences - Agreement Features, WARNING: In
Pronouns you said that your language has dependent pronouns and makes a distinction between singluar and plural forms of the pronouns, yet you have not checked any singular or plural features here. It is therefore most likely that you need to check some or all of the singular and plural features above. Otherwise, please return to
Pronouns (first page) and change your answer to ‘No, the pronouns only mark person’, but that will mean that any forms you keyed in the textboxes for plural will not be included in any output.

From

Basic Sentences - Subjunctives, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these subjunctive condition markers occur with respect to the rest of the subjunctive conditional phrase in your language, or change the answer to one of the ‘No’ answers above.

Negative Constructions, on the first page, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these negative elements occur in your language, or change the answer above to ‘No, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase’.

From

From
Negative Constructions - Adverbial and Auxiliary Elements, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where these negative words occur in your language, or change the answer above as to how the negative temporal adverbs are related to the positive forms.

From
Negative Constructions - Adverbial and Auxiliary Elements, WARNING - The answers you have entered are incompatible!! A negative auxiliary word cannot require the presence of another auxiliary if your language does not have (positive) auxiliaries that are written as independent words. Please change your answer either here or in
Basic Sentences - Auxiliaries to correct this problem before proceeding.

From
Negative Constructions - Adverbial and Auxiliary Elements, WARNING - The answers you have entered are incompatible!! A negative auxiliary affix cannot attach to anything if your language does not have (positive) auxiliaries that are written as independent words. Please change your answer either here or in
Basic Sentences - Auxiliaries to correct this problem before proceeding.

From
Coordination Constructions, on the first page, WARNING: You did not check any boxes to describe how the conjunctions may attach in your language. Please check one or more boxes as appropriate, or change your answer above to ‘Yes, they are all independent words’.

From
Focus and Topic Constructions, WARNING: You did not check any boxes to describe where the topic marker may occur with respect to the topic phrase in your language. Please check one or more boxes, or change your answer to ‘No, the topic is unmarked except for position’ above, in which case you should not have any examples of topic markers in the box either.

From
Focus and Topic Constructions, WARNING: You did not check any boxes to describe where the focus marker may occur with respect to the focus phrase in your language. Please check one or more boxes, or change your answer to ‘No, the focused phrase is unmarked except for position’ above, in which case you should not have any examples of focus markers in the box either.

From
Exclamations, Greetings and Interjections, WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe where the words which mark an exclamation may occur in your language, or change the answer above to ‘No’. In that case there should not be examples in the textbox above.
form.introduction:
Once there are no WARNING messages showing above, we suggest you also recheck the main page in
Pronouns to make sure it asked you for the correct number of sets of pronouns for your language. If not, please follow the instructions there about changing your answer in
Overall Typology Questions - Case System. If you do make a change regarding the case system it will change many other answers throughout, so be sure to return here after redoing the pronouns to see if any new WARNING messages need to be taken care of.
You have now completed the PAWS Starter Kit. Please save the PC-Patr grammar file (.grm) with a different name before editing it. Contact Cheri_Black@sil.org for help on how to proceed or how to handle specific constructions if you are using PC-Patr for parsing and disambiguation. You may view the grammar drafts by double clicking on the .htm files.
Please save the .xml versions under a different file name before you begin editing. For a nice XML editor for the grammar writeup, we personally prefer the XMLMind XML Editor It makes editing and printing a pdf version much easier, since special addons are available to handle all the extra features of XLingPaper, which the grammar writeup is using. You can find out more information at http://www.xlingpaper.org/.
You may now exit PAWS for your final time. Congratulations!
